text: hello welcome my name is Andrew chud I'm a senior software developer on the AWS
mobile developer experience team and today I'm gonna be talking about integrating video into mobile apps and
websites so I'm going to talk about some
the different types of applications that use video I'm going to talk about some
of the types of services that those applications require some of the problems that they run into when trying to deliver video content to mobile
devices and I'm going to talk about some of the solutions that AWS has to offer to solve some of those problems I'm
going to talk about some examples software architectures and I'm going to launch one of those architectures live
and integrate it with a mobile app and website I'm going to talk about some of
the new media services that launched this week at reinvent from the AWS elemental team and I'm going to talk
about testing on AWS device farm so at
AWS we're always really excited and proud to be part of our customers great success stories and mobile video apps
are no exception to that so we have a we have a number of customers a lot of
different types of customers that use video as part of their products for
example a Baima TV is a leading media services company in Japan with their fresh platform that has 1,400 channels
of content over 37,000 programs available for streaming built on top of AWS you have some companies that started
in conventional television broadcasting like PBS that now stream besides their
360 member television stations they now stream content through websites and apps
with with PBS org pbskids.org and a PBS video and you have companies that like
do app where their business is delivering customized video apps for
other organizations so do app produces 460 video apps for news organizations in
150 marketplaces in the US all of these built on top of AWS services
so generally the video apps and websites fall into a few categories they're using video on-demand streaming where they've
got some some static content that is streamed to devices they have broadcast
they're doing live streaming broadcast for example sports and news events or
they're doing some kind of peer-to-peer communication for example chat apps or video teleconferencing for example and
all of these types of apps run into some of the same problems mainly around the fact that they're going to mobile
devices they are going over the the air as far as their interface they have an
RF interface and the problems with an RF interface are it's it's lossy you end up
with a lot of packet loss you end up with retransmissions which means higher latency in getting the data to the devices and source content is generally
very high resolution they're very high bandwidth sort of formats so your source
content for your video is going to be 4k or it's going to be 1080p and those files are very large so you combine that
with with a unreliable over-the-air interface and you run into some problems
trying to deliver consistent smooth stream of video to your devices you may
also have issues for example if you're on Wi-Fi where you're on a network that's throttled you might be at the
airport you might be at your hotel and you might you might have your data rate throttled down to a pretty low level so
if you tried to play a high-resolution video stream in that environment you would end up sitting there with the with
a loading spinner buffering your video which would be a really bad experience
and add to that that you you have the the normal conditions of having to go
over Network hops on the actual the internet also you also have to protect
your content which is true whether you're on a mobile device or or not so
these are some of the problems that you run into so some of the ways that you can deal with those problems with AWS
solutions one is to use a CDN so if you use a content delivery network like
Amazon Cloud front you can deliver that cached content from edge servers that are close they're
physically close to your actual customers and their mobile devices so you reduce the number of Network hops
that are going between the the source of your content and the access point for
your RF interface to your mobile devices you reduce the number of hops they're reduce the latency there and it improves
the the overall network conditions so Amazon CloudFront has 107 points of
presence worldwide in 55 cities and 24 countries so you can get those edge servers where you can cache your content
stream your content very close to your actual devices no matter where your customers are and again streaming the
original source content which is going to be very high resolution is not convenient over a lossy network so you
want to transcode that high resolution video down to formats that are lower
bandwidth they're lower quality formats that will transmit more easily over-the-air and a great way to do that
is to use an adaptive multi bitrate format so something like MPEG DASH or
HTTP Live Streaming that takes your video converts it into multiple lower resolution formats in equal time slices
and the client on your mobile device can determine based on the network conditions how high of a resolution it
can go and still keep a smooth stream of video for your mobile devices and your viewer and if the network conditions
improve your client can step up to a higher resolution and have a better better quality video so here's examples
of some of the different sort of encoding bit rates that you might use and flip between these depending on what
the network conditions are to protect your content a common
solution is to encrypt your data to encrypt the actual files so the the segments of video that are delivered to
the device are actually encrypted and the device the player on the device contacts a license server to get a key
to decrypt each segment of video so it's a time-limited key that's only going to work for a certain amount of time the
user on the device will authenticate with whatever your identity provider is in your system that gives them access to
those keys to decrypt the data and you can also use authorization to control
access to specific URLs per specific content so again your user your user
identifies themselves with an authentication service that's coordinated to an authorization component which will only vend the URLs
to devices that are allowed to see that content so this picture is is a
generalized service architecture as an example that you might use for streaming live video and in this in this slide
we're using the mobile device as the source for the video also which may not always be the case if you're
broadcasting a live sports event or news event your source would be something else and this is the architecture you'll
see on a lot of mobile services in general it's this isn't significantly different than other mobile services
where you have an identity service so your users of your mobile app will sign in with the login and password through
some identity provider that's going to enable access control through an
authorization service you're going to have a service layer that's doing all your heavy lifting and business logic of
your application so for video that's going to mean encoding your video doing transcoding possibly encrypting your
video packaging it maybe you have watermarks maybe you have ad injection into your video that's all going to
happen in your service layer and the contents going to be vended out through
your content delivery network to again provide the least number of network hops
out on the internet and cache content whenever possible as close to the device
so this is a much more specific architecture that is really a video-on-demand architecture but more in
the context of a a social networking kind of app so again your sources your
mobile devices and here the mobile device authenticates with Amazon Cognito
so the user signs in to a Cognito user pool or some other identity provider that Amazon Cognito is going to federate
and it allows the device to directly use Amazon s3 simple storage service without
a middle tier of software so because of the the fine-grained access control
policies that are constructed over s3 you can use s3 directly from the mobile
app so in this architecture users of the device will upload a video in the s3
bucket it will trigger a notification which will invoke an AWS lambda function the lambda function will read that file
out of s3 it'll create a job in elastic transcoder services which is our video transcoding service elastic transcoder
will read the source file convert it to those other media formats for example the HTTP Live Streaming format we talked
about it'll construct a playlist which is a single single manifest for that
video with all the different video formats that it can ratchet up and down between and it'll put that into the
other s3 bucket and deliver it through the content delivery network which is cloud from so we're going to build this
architecture today I'm gonna launch it live everything I'm going to do is going to be directly out of a github
repository so you can do the same thing in your own account I'm going to talk about how these resources are deployed
so the the resources you see on the client side which are close to the
devices are all going to be configured by AWS mobile hub AWS mobile hub is our
mobile developer portal which basically makes it very easy to configure a number
of AWS services together to work together to enable use cases that are
convenient for mobile apps so for this project I'm going to use Cognito user pools for authentication I'm going to
use the user data storage feature in mobile hub for my video ingestion for
the upload peace and I'm going to use the hosting and streaming feature in mobile hub which will enable the CloudFront distribution and my hosting s3 bucket to
